articles.abstract: Business travelers like Michelle Madhok used to consider online hotel reviews a reliable reference.      Whenever she traveled to an unfamiliar city, Ms. Madhok said, she clicked on sites like TripAdvisor.com or IgoUgo.com, where she found thousands of ratings written by real guests.

articles.headline: Top Aide Defends Domestic Spying
articles.snippet: President Bush decided against allowing the National Security Agency to intercept purely domestic phone calls and e-mail messages after the Sept. 11 attacks in part because officials realized such a decision would provoke intense opposition if mad...
articles.abstract: President Bush decided against allowing the National Security Agency to intercept purely domestic phone calls and e-mail messages after the Sept. 11 attacks in part because officials realized such a decision would provoke intense opposition if made public, Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales testified Monday.     Mr. Bush was intent on striking ''the right balance'' between national security and privacy interests, Mr. Gonzales said at the start of Congressional hearings into the N.S.A. program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 - President Bush decided against allowing the National Security Agency to intercept purely domestic phone calls and e-mail messages after the Sept. 11 attacks in part because officials realized such a decision would provoke intense opposition if made public, Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales testified Monday.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and James Risen

articles.headline: Record Sales of Sleeping Pills Are Causing Worries
articles.snippet: Americans are taking sleeping pills like never before, fueled by frenetic workdays that do not go gently into a great night's sleep, and lulled by a surge of consumer advertising that promises safe slumber with minimal side effects.      About 42 ...
articles.abstract: Americans are taking sleeping pills like never before, fueled by frenetic workdays that do not go gently into a great night's sleep, and lulled by a surge of consumer advertising that promises safe slumber with minimal side effects.      About 42 million sleeping pill prescriptions were filled last year, according to the research company IMS Health, up nearly 60 percent since 2000.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans are taking sleeping pills like never before, fueled by frenetic workdays that do not go gently into a great night's sleep, and lulled by a surge of consumer advertising that promises safe slumber with minimal side effects.

articles.headline: A Detective to the Stars Is Accused of Wiretaps
articles.snippet: Anthony Pellicano, the deposed detective to the stars, masterminded a sprawling wiretapping ring that helped his clients gain an advantage in disputes with opponents including actors, reporters and talent managers, federal prosecutors said on Mond...
articles.abstract: Anthony Pellicano, the deposed detective to the stars, masterminded a sprawling wiretapping ring that helped his clients gain an advantage in disputes with opponents including actors, reporters and talent managers, federal prosecutors said on Monday.     Prosecutors said that among the people who had been illegally wiretapped or subjected to criminal background checks were the actors Sylvester Stallone, Keith Carradine, Garry Shandling and Kevin Nealon; a Hollywood reporter for The New York Times; and managers of the Creative Artists talent agency.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger and Allison Hope Weiner

York, an adviser to G.M.'s biggest individual investor, the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian.     G.M. also said that E. articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Feb. 6 - Opening its doors to a high-profile critic, the General Motors Corporation gave a seat on its board on Monday to Jerome B. York, an adviser to G.M.'s biggest individual investor, the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian.

articles.headline: Toys 'R' Us Said to Name a New Chief
articles.snippet: Toys ''R'' Us, the nation's largest specialty toy retailer, has chosen Gerald L. Storch, the former vice chairman of the Target Corporation, as it next chief executive, a position left vacant since the chain's sale last year, people briefed on the...
articles.abstract: Toys ''R'' Us, the nation's largest specialty toy retailer, has chosen Gerald L. Storch, the former vice chairman of the Target Corporation, as it next chief executive, a position left vacant since the chain's sale last year, people briefed on the decision said last night.      The surprise selection of Mr. Storch, which is expected to be announced as early as today, is an indication that Toys ''R'' Us is reaching outside the company -- searching for a chief executive with experience at a major rival -- as it seeks growth in the ailing toy industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Toys "R" Us, the nation's largest specialty toy retailer, has chosen Gerald L. Storch, the former vice chairman of the Target Corporation, as it next chief executive, a position left vacant since the chain's sale last year, people briefed on the decision said last night.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: In Limelight at Wiretap Hearing: 2 Laws, but Which Should Rule?
articles.snippet: It is the sort of problem that judges confront every day. One law forbids a certain activity. The other may allow it. Which one counts?     Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales made the case to the Senate Judiciary Committee yesterday that two pot...
articles.abstract: It is the sort of problem that judges confront every day. One law forbids a certain activity. The other may allow it. Which one counts?     Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales made the case to the Senate Judiciary Committee yesterday that two potentially contradictory Congressional actions -- one a 1978 law forbidding domestic surveillance without a court's permission, the other a 2001 resolution giving the president authority to use force to combat Al Qaeda -- together mean that the executive branch is free to decide on its own to spy on communications between people in the United States and those abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is the sort of problem that judges confront every day. One law forbids a certain activity. The other may allow it. Which one counts?

articles.headline: Bush Budget Plan for $2.77 Trillion Stresses Security
articles.snippet: President Bush proposed a $2.77 trillion budget on Monday calling for increased spending on the military and domestic security and substantial cuts in domestic programs as disparate as education, farm subsidies and the national parks.     The budg...
articles.abstract: President Bush proposed a $2.77 trillion budget on Monday calling for increased spending on the military and domestic security and substantial cuts in domestic programs as disparate as education, farm subsidies and the national parks.     The budget bears all the hallmarks of the Bush presidency: his overriding priorities are national security and making permanent the tax cuts passed by Congress in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 - President Bush proposed a $2.77 trillion budget on Monday calling for increased spending on the military and domestic security and substantial cuts in domestic programs as disparate as education, farm subsidies and the national parks.

articles.headline: Hoping a Small Sample May Signal a Cure
articles.snippet: Joshua Boger might have finally found his billion-dollar molecule.      Mr. Boger, the brash founder and chief executive of Vertex Pharmaceuticals, was profiled, along with his company, in a 1994 book ''The Billion-Dollar Molecule: One Company's Q...
articles.abstract: Joshua Boger might have finally found his billion-dollar molecule.      Mr. Boger, the brash founder and chief executive of Vertex Pharmaceuticals, was profiled, along with his company, in a 1994 book ''The Billion-Dollar Molecule: One Company's Quest for the Perfect Drug.'' But the drug discussed in the book never made it to market, and after more than 16 years in business and losses totaling about $1 billion, Vertex has still not hit it big.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joshua Boger might have finally found his billion-dollar molecule.
